Easy.text: Explain what a variable is and why it's important in programming.
Easy.sample_answer: A variable is a named container that stores a value. It's important because it allows us to store, retrieve, and manipulate data during program execution.
Easy.follow_up: Can you give an example of how you'd use a variable?

Easy.text: What's the difference between a list and a dictionary?
Easy.sample_answer: A list is an ordered collection of items accessed by index, while a dictionary is an unordered collection of key-value pairs accessed by key.
Easy.follow_up: When would you use a dictionary instead of a list?

Easy.text: What is version control and why is it used?
Easy.sample_answer: Version control tracks changes to code and allows multiple developers to work on the same project. It provides history, branching, and collaboration features.
Easy.follow_up: Have you used Git before? What commands do you use most?

Intermediate.text: Describe the differences between classes and objects in OOP.
Intermediate.sample_answer: A class is a blueprint or template that defines properties and methods. An object is an instance of a class with specific values.
Intermediate.follow_up: How does inheritance work with classes?

Intermediate.text: Explain the time and space complexity of a binary search.
Intermediate.sample_answer: Binary search has O(log n) time complexity because it halves the search space with each iteration, and O(1) space complexity if iterative.
Intermediate.follow_up: What are the requirements for binary search to work?

Intermediate.text: What is a REST API and what are the main HTTP methods?
Intermediate.sample_answer: REST is an architectural style for web services. Main methods are GET (retrieve), POST (create), PUT (update), DELETE (remove), and PATCH (partial update).
Intermediate.follow_up: What's the difference between PUT and PATCH?

Hard.text: Design a caching strategy for a distributed system. What trade-offs exist?
Hard.sample_answer: A multi-level cache (local, distributed like Redis) reduces latency. Trade-offs include consistency (cache invalidation is hard), memory cost, and complexity.
Hard.follow_up: How would you handle cache invalidation at scale?

Hard.text: Explain the CAP theorem and its implications for distributed databases.
Hard.sample_answer: CAP states you can have at most 2 of: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance. Most systems choose AP or CP. This affects design decisions.
Hard.follow_up: Which would you prioritize in a financial system and why?

Hard.text: How would you debug a memory leak in a production system?
Hard.sample_answer: Monitor memory usage, use profiling tools, identify the growing object, check for circular references, use heap dumps, and implement automated memory monitoring.
Hard.follow_up: What tools have you used for memory profiling?

Expert.text: Architect a system that handles 1M concurrent users. What are the key challenges?
Expert.sample_answer: Key challenges: load balancing, database sharding, caching, horizontal scaling, connection pooling, message queues, and monitoring. Use microservices, CDN, and auto-scaling.
Expert.follow_up: How would you handle the database layer for this scale?

Easy.text: What is the difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
Easy.sample_answer: Supervised learning uses labeled data to train models (classification, regression). Unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data (clustering, dimensionality reduction).
Easy.follow_up: Can you name some algorithms for each type?

Easy.text: How do you measure model performance?
Easy.sample_answer: Use metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score for classification; MSE, RMSE, RÂ² for regression. Choose metrics based on problem type and priorities.
Easy.follow_up: When would you use precision over accuracy?

Intermediate.text: Explain feature engineering and its importance.
Intermediate.sample_answer: Feature engineering creates meaningful features from raw data. It's crucial because good features improve model performance more than complex algorithms.
Intermediate.follow_up: What techniques do you use for feature selection?

Hard.text: How do you handle class imbalance in classification problems?
Hard.sample_answer: Techniques include oversampling, undersampling, SMOTE, class weights, and using appropriate metrics (not accuracy). Choose based on business requirements.
Hard.follow_up: Can you explain SMOTE in detail?

Easy.text: What does a product manager do?
Easy.sample_answer: A PM bridges business, engineering, and user needs. They define product vision, prioritize features, work with teams, and measure success.

Intermediate.text: How would you approach building a new feature?
Intermediate.sample_answer: 1) Understand user needs, 2) Define requirements, 3) Prioritize with business impact, 4) Collaborate with design/engineering, 5) Launch and measure success.
Intermediate.follow_up: How do you measure success for a feature?

Hard.text: How would you decide to kill a feature that's not working?
Hard.sample_answer: Analyze metrics vs. goals, consider sunk cost fallacy, get stakeholder input, communicate clearly, and have a plan for existing users.
Hard.follow_up: Tell me about a time you had to make a difficult decision.

Easy.text: What is the difference between Docker and a VM?
Easy.sample_answer: Docker containers are lightweight, contain only the app and dependencies, share the OS kernel. VMs are heavier, virtualize the entire OS.
Easy.follow_up: What are the benefits of using containers?

Intermediate.sample_answer: CI/CD automates testing and deployment. CI runs tests on every commit. CD pushes to production. Benefits: faster releases, fewer bugs, quick feedback.
Intermediate.follow_up: What tools do you use for CI/CD?

Hard.text: Design a resilient Kubernetes deployment for a critical service.
Hard.sample_answer: Use multiple replicas, resource limits, health checks, auto-scaling, rolling updates, multi-zone deployment, persistent storage, and monitoring/alerting.
Hard.follow_up: How would you handle database failover?

Easy.text: Explain the difference between client-side and server-side rendering.
Easy.sample_answer: Client-side rendering builds HTML in the browser via JavaScript. Server-side rendering builds HTML on the server. CSR is faster after load, SSR is better for SEO.
Easy.follow_up: When would you choose one over the other?

Intermediate.text: What are React hooks and why are they useful?
Intermediate.sample_answer: Hooks let you use state and side effects in functional components. Benefits: code reuse, simpler logic, better organization without class complexity.

Hard.text: Design a performant, scalable state management solution for a large app.
Hard.sample_answer: Use Redux/Zustand for global state, localStorage for persistence, lazy loading, code splitting, memoization, and consider GraphQL for data fetching and caching.
Hard.follow_up: How would you handle async operations in Redux?
